course_title: Topics in German Culture and Civilization: Green Germany
class_notes:
Course Title: Green Germany.
Class will meet in Candler Library 216.


Course description: This upper-level course conducted in German examines the history and impact of environmental awareness on German culture, society, and politics. The course consists of three thematic units: 
1.	Die Natur im deutschen Bewu√ütsein: an exploration of the roots of German environmental consciousness by examining the portrayal of nature in select texts from the 18th to 20th century; 
2.	Umweltschutz in der BRD und der DDR: 1950-2010: a chronological exploration of key developments in ecological awareness in both West and East Germany; 
3.	Globale und lokale Initiativen gegen den Klimawandel: a contemporary examination of current measures being undertaken to combat climate change, with a focus on both global initiatives (e.g., Paris Accords) and local efforts at the university and in Atlanta.
For the third thematic unit, students will engage in weekly synchronous telecollaborative meetings with university students in Bavaria, Germany to discuss and compare local environmental initiatives (not) being undertaken at the respective institutions and municipalities to address climate change and environmental injustice. These practices will also be discussed in terms of their reflection of larger cultural, societal, and political norms. This telecollaborative engagement will culminate in an online project to highlight both eco-friendly features of the respective localities as well as areas in need of environmental attention.


Texts: 
-	Required course materials will be available via Canvas
-	Auf den Punkt Gebracht: Deutscher Lernwortschatz Zur Textarbeit. (2013). Klett Verlag. ISBN 978-3125195677
-	Students should own a good reference grammar book (e.g., Rankin & Wells).


Assessment:
Preparation and participation 25%
Oral presentations 15%
Writing tasks 35%
Collaborative curation of online project 25%


Prerequisites:  Two German courses numbered 300 or higher or its equivalent or permission of instructor.
course_description: An interdisciplinary course intended to provide a comprehensive, historically oriented overview of the formative elements, influences, and movements of German culture and civilization. Taught in German.
